text: so here it is the Apple watch now this
is one of three versions that are going
to be available in different finishes
and they start at $349 this particular
one all of them actually have magnets so
it's very easy to loop and clasp around
your wrist now what I'm looking at here
actually is a video demo on the watch
there aren't any watches that are
available for press to wear and try out
but you get a sense of how it performs
I've just felt the taptic feedback which
is basically a sophisticated way of
saying the way that it alerts you and
it's not a traditional vibration it's
more like a ping on your wrist and it
does feel a little different from a
traditional vibration the other notable
features about it are the digital crown
so instead of just having a regular
crown on a watch this crown here when
you rotate it will zoom in for example
to the home screen it will zoom in to
maps and allow you to navigate around
the watch there's another feature and
another button just underneath it which
is access for something called digital
taps and that's a way of getting up your
contacts and for example sending them
emails or messages and responding to
them even with custom gestures I have to
say that last bit does feel a little
gimmicky now in terms of the back of the
watch there are various features there's
infrared sensors and LEDs here as well
which will all together go toward
counting your heartbeat and your heart
rates and they'll interact with your
iPhone to give you an all-round idea of
how fit you are and how much walking for
example you're doing during a day
there's also a magnet on here for
inductive charging so you literally just
snap a charger onto the back
magnetically and Apple says that the
batteries should last all day though
we've heard similar claims from other
manufacturers and all day maybe pushing
it we have no idea yet this watch isn't
available until early next year we'll
find out more about it then
